sv:property.sv:value: Text shown in the global page footer.

Every website comes with its own styling requirements. Hippo's setup application can therefore not address site styling. Instead, the generated pages use minimal styling to render the content. It is the task of the Hippo developer to adjust the front-end to the site's needs.

The Agriculture and Rural Economy Directorate of the Scottish Government, description and responsibilities.
The Agriculture and Rural Economy Directorate's description and responsibilities.

What we do

We promote sustainable economic growth in agriculture, the food industry, and in rural areas.

We are responsible for:

  • agricultural policy
  • engaging with other parts of the UK and EU in development of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP)
  • rural land management, with the aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions
  • supporting locally-led development in rural communities
  • preventing, controlling and eradicating animal disease in Scotland
  • enhancing animal welfare
  • providing scientific services and advice on agricultural and environmental matters

Elinor Mitchell's role, responsibilities and biography.
Elinor Mitchell's role, responsibilities and biography. Elinor is Director of Agriculture and Rural Economy Directorate.

Biography

Elinor Mitchell was appointed as Director of Agriculture, Food and Rural Communities (subsequently renamed Agriculture and Rural Economy Directorate) in September 2016. She joined the civil service in 1988, starting her career in Whitehall and then moving to Scotland.

Her previous posts within Scottish Government include:

  • Director of HR and Organisational Development (secondment post), Scottish Ambulance Service
  • Acting Director for Local Government and Communities
  • Lead for Public Services Reform, Democratic Renewal and Community Empowerment
  • Deputy Director, HR

She has held other senior roles within Scottish Government in a range of policy areas, these include:

  • Health
  • Environment
  • Fisheries
  • Social Justice

Elinor was born and brought up in Glasgow and studied for a degree on Nursing at Glasgow University. She is also a chartered fellow of the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD), and Chartered Institute of Management Accounts (CIMA) qualified.

Director of Agriculture, Food and Rural Communities
Saughton House
Broomhouse Drive
Edinburgh
EH11 3XD
The Chief Vet is Sheila Voas who is responsible for advising ministers.
The Chief Vet is responsible for advising ministers.

The Chief Vet is responsible for providing veterinary advice to Scottish Ministers and leading on animal health and welfare for Scotland.

The role includes protecting human health through the control of zoonotic diseases (those which spread between animals and humans). Responsibilities also include preventing, controling or eradicating notifiable diseases such as avian influenza, foot and mouth disease, rabies and TB, thereby maintaining or opening trade routes.

Another aspect of the job is to encourage high health standards to increase productivity and efficiency, and to drive improved standards of animal welfare in all species.
The Chief Vet is Sheila Voas who is responsible for advising ministers.

The Advanced Learning and Science Directorate of the Scottish Government, description and responsibilities.
The Advanced Learning and Science Directorate's description and responsibilities.

What we do

We deliver further and higher education in Scotland. This includes student support and science.

We are responsible for:

  • developing the young workforce and tackling youth unemployment
  • maintaining access to higher education based on the ability to learn and not the ability to pay
  • creating the educated workforce required to help drive sustainable economic growth
  • championing science, and the use of scientific advice to inform policy-making
  • realising the benefits of college regionalisation

The Directorate also has sponsorship responsibility for the Scottish Funding Council.
Aileen McKechine's role, responsibilities and biography. Aileen is Director for Advanced Learning and Science in the Scottish Government.
Aileen McKechine's role, responsibilities and biography. Aileen is Director for Advanced Learning and Science.

Aileen McKechnie has been Director of Advanced Learning and Science since January 2015.

Responsibilities

The Director of Advanced Learning and Science is responsible for the delivery of further and higher education, championing science through engagement, developing the young workforce, and fulfilling the 'Fraser Figure' role for the Student Awards Agency for Scotland (SAAS).

Biography

Prior to this appointment, Aileen was Director of Culture and Heritage. She is the Senior Responsible Officer for the Developing the Young Workforce programme.

She has worked in a variety of roles within the Scottish Government for 15 years covering higher education, culture, economy, external affairs and industry. She is a language graduate from Glasgow University where she also completed an MBA.
Role, responsibilities and biography. Professor Scott is Commissioner for Fair Access to Higher Education.
Role, responsibilities and biography. Sir Professor Scott is Commissioner for Fair Access to Higher Education.
commissioner for fair access to higher education

Sir Professor Scott was appointed Commissioner for Fair Access in December 2016.

Responsibilities and functions

The Commissioner is independent of government and responsible for leading a system wide effort to deliver fair access in Scotland, including the development of a framework for fair access.

He provides impartial policy advice to the Scottish Government and other organisations and works across the entire education system to:

  • develop best practice
  • improve the evidence base
  • hold to account all those with a role in advancing fair access to higher education

The Commissioner holds a non-statutory role. He is not an ombudsman or regulator and is not able to take forward individual cases.

The functions of the Commissioner for Fair Access are to:

  • lead cohesive and system wide efforts to drive fair access in Scotland; acting as an advocate for access for disadvantaged learners and holding to account those with a role to play in achieving equal access, including ministers and the Scottish Funding Council (SFC)
  • co-ordinate and prioritise the development of a more substantial evidence base on the issues most pertinent to fair access, including the commissioning and publication of independent research and the development of a framework for fair access
  • publish an annual report to ministers outlining the Commissioner's views on progress towards equal access in Scotland to inform development of effective policy at national, regional and institutional level

Biography

Peter is Professor of Higher Education studies at University College London. Before that he was Vice-Chancellor of Kingston University and Pro Vice-Chancellor for external affairs at the University of Leeds. He was a member of the board of the Higher Education Funding Council for England where he chaired its widening participation strategic committee.

His earlier career was spent in journalism and he was Editor of the Times Higher Education.

He was knighted in 2007 for services to education and is the recipient of a number of honorary degrees. He has published widely on education, including widening access issues.

Related policies

  • universities
  • colleges

Documents

  • disabled students at university: discussion paper
  • statement on HESA entrant statistics 2017-2018
  • Commissioner for Fair Access discussion paper: retention, outcomes and destinations
  • Commissioner for Fair Access: annual report 2017
  • league tables: discussion paper: November 2017
  • contextual higher education admissions: discussion paper: June 2017
  • university and college admissions, offers and acceptances: discussion paper: June 2017

Speeches and presentations

  • Scottish Credit and Qualifications Framework conference: February 2018
  • Leadership Foundation for Higher Education: February 2018
  • Forum for Access and Continuing Education: July 2017
  • Scottish Funding Council's Fair Access Conference: June 2017
  • Quality Assurance Agency Scotland Conference: June 2017
  • UCAS Scottish Standing Group: June 2017
  • Open University Scotland widening access seminar: June 2017
  • Scottish Parliament cross party group on colleges and universities: June 2017

Commissioner for Fair Access
6th Floor Atlantic Quay
Scottish Government
150 Broomielaw
Glasgow
G2 8LU

Tel: 0131 244 1266

Professor Sheila Rowan MBE's role, responsibilities and biography. Sheila is Chief Scientific Adviser (CSA) for the Scottish Government.
Professor Sheila Rowan MBE's role, responsibilities and biography. Sheila is Chief Scientific Adviser (CSA) for the Scottish Government.

Professor Sheila Rowan was appointed Chief Scientific Adviser (CSA) for Scotland in June 2016.

This is a part-time position. Sheila also remains Director of the Institute for Gravitational Research, University of Glasgow, a position she has held since 2009. She received an MBE in 2011.

Responsibilities

The CSA is responsible for informing policy development to benefit the economy, people and environment of Scotland. She works closely with the Scottish Science Advisory Council, of which she is an ex officio member, to advise the Scottish Government across all areas of its work.

Biography

Sheila's research is targeted at developing optical materials for use in gravitational wave detectors, and her recent work has been a crucial part of the Advanced LIGO upgrades, carried out between 2010 and 2015, that contributed to one of the most significant scientific breakthroughs of this century: the first detection of gravitational waves announced in February 2016. This resulted in a share of the 2016 Special Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics for her and the members of her team in Glasgow.
The Scottish Government, St Andrew's House, Regent Road, Edinburgh, EH1 3DG
